title: integer overflow in curl_escape caused heap corruption

activities.message:
Hi.

Why all of my integer overflow here just get 500 bounty? Did you consider about the impact of this vuln could make?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi.

Why all of my integer overflow here just get 500 bounty? Did you consider about the impact of this vuln could make?

activities.message: Our assumption is that remote exploitation is dependent upon specific application configurations and therefore not applicable universally. Do you believe that RCE is reliably achieved in most common application configurations? If so, could you provide an exploit scenario against a typical application?
activities.markdown_message: Our assumption is that remote exploitation is dependent upon specific application configurations and therefore not applicable universally. Do you believe that RCE is reliably achieved in most common application configurations? If so, could you provide an exploit scenario against a typical application?

activities.message:
What did you mean "in most common application configurations"? 

As your description: "Medium Demonstrate that remote exploitation of this bug is very likely (e.g. good control a register)."

For the Medium requirement, the integer overflow in string len in PHP is very easy to lead to heap overflow (you can check my PoC in the reports). And some case, as I has here, the result of exploit using this integer overflow is  arbitrary memory read. If you want the PoC for this, I can send you.

Regards.
activities.markdown_message:
What did you mean "in most common application configurations"?

As your description: "Medium Demonstrate that remote exploitation of this bug is very likely (e.g. good control a register)."

For the Medium requirement, the integer overflow in string len in PHP is very easy to lead to heap overflow (you can check my PoC in the reports). And some case, as I has here, the result of exploit using this integer overflow is arbitrary memory read. If you want the PoC for this, I can send you.

Regards.

activities.message:
> What did you mean "in most common application configurations"?

Vulnerabilities that are only exploitable in uncommon or rare configurations are treated as lower severity. That seems to be the case with these integer overflows, because exploitation depends upon an application that performs an unsafe operation with the integer (and likely disables memory-limit as well). This is a probable scenario (which is why these are eligible!) but not likely to occur in a large number of applications, reducing the severity.

If you believe this assessment is inaccurate, could you please demonstrate a PoC against any common (widely-deployed) application?

If you believe this assessment is inaccurate, could you please demonstrate a PoC against any common (widely-deployed) application?

activities.message:
So, it must be a vuln affected widely-deployed application?

I also checked your description, there are nothing like this "widely-deployed". It just mentioned something like how hard to exploit the vuln. And you can check, there are easy to achieve the Medium level by this kind of vuln!

So now, if you - the panel - want to bring the "widely-deployed application" as a requirement for the bounty, please announce to all hackers there to know and modified your description.

But before you do that, I don't think all of my report will be checked against the "widely-deployed application" requirement. Because, a lot of report before was reward without checking this such thing, and this check applied to my reports made me feel unfair!

Thanks.

activities.message:
> Only critical vulnerabilities that demonstrate complete compromise of the system's integrity or confidentiality are eligible for a bounty - typically Arbitrary Code Execution or equivalent impact. While we encourage you to submit all potential issues, **lower severity issues (such as those only exploitable in rare configurations) are not in scope at this time**.

Thank you for pointing this out. I see how this portion of our severity assessment is not written as clearly as it should be, and I will raise this issue with the panel to investigate updating the program policy to state it more directly. We have a long track record of awarding the minimum bounty in this program for valid but lower severity issues.
activities.markdown_message:

While we encourage you to submit all potential issues, lower severity issues (such as those only exploitable in rare configurations) are not in scope at this time.

Thank you for pointing this out. I see how this portion of our severity assessment is not written as clearly as it should be, and I will raise this issue with the panel to investigate updating the program policy to state it more directly. We have a long track record of awarding the minimum bounty in this program for valid but lower severity issues.

activities.message:
Ok,

I respected the decision of the panel. But your decisions was disunion. Some vulns reported to PHP was the "exploitable in rare configurations" but still considered as Medium. Included my 3 reports last 2 months.

So now, should you review all the rewards you was made and take it back? I'll not be happy if I was downgrade my reward, but I'll do that.

I hate the thing like this! Some case, people decided to to this. But with the same another problems, they not. 

Regards.

activities.message:
minhrau, sorry again for the disappointment. We've taken an action item to clarify the program's policy. But this award is in line with what we've consistently awarded for similar issues: vulnerabilities that are unlikely to be widely exploitable are awarded the minimum category. We'll never be perfectly consistent here as a large part of this assessment is based on probability.

In the case of #55017, that amount was for 10 different vulnerabilities, most of which were awarded the minimum $500 (we've since implemented a policy to require each vulnerability to be submitted individually to avoid this confusion).

If you still believe this issue has higher impact than we've reflected here, you can best help us by demonstrating RCE in a production application:

> If you believe this assessment is inaccurate, could you please demonstrate a PoC against any common (widely-deployed) application?

Thank you.

If you still believe this issue has higher impact than we've reflected here, you can best help us by demonstrating RCE in a production application:

If you believe this assessment is inaccurate, could you please demonstrate a PoC against any common (widely-deployed) application?

Thank you.

activities.message:
Hi,

Don't tell me that seem i did not know anything. That lame!

Every single one vuln in report #55017 is kind of integer overflow AND as you think it is "rare configuration".

And, I also have same kind of "rare configuration" - as you though - but still considered as Medium. 

I don't believe that the vuln I discovered is easy RCE, BUT it must be treated the same as what other bugs was treated as.

Regards.
